<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_increment_response_rc:
```c
void
MHD_increment_response_rc (struct MHD_Response *response)
{
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ (&response->mutex);
#endif
  (response->reference_count)++;
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ (&response->mutex);
#endif
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function MHD_increment_response_rc:
#define MHD_mutex_lock_chk_(pmutex) do{if(!MHD_mutex_lock_(pmutex))MHD_PANIC(_("Failed to lock mutex.\n"));\
}while(0)
...
#define MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_(pmutex) do{if(!MHD_mutex_unlock_(pmutex))MHD_PANIC(_("Failed to unlock mutex.\n"));\
}while(0)
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
#define MHD_mutex_lock_chk_(pmutex) do{if(!MHD_mutex_lock_(pmutex))MHD_PANIC(_("Failed to lock mutex.\n"));\
}while(0)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in the shown fragment. The macro MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ merely expands to a call to the function MHD_mutex_lock_ and to MHD_PANIC; the macro itself is not a function and does not call itself. Rule 17.2 would be violated only if one of the called functions were implemented so that it (directly or indirectly) called back into MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ or into a function that uses it, e.g. if MHD_mutex_lock_ were implemented as: bool MHD_mutex_lock_(pmutex){ MHD_mutex_lock_chk_(pmutex); return true; } which would create infinite recursion.
